Den 5. sep. 2012 18:03 skrev "Rushforth, Peter" <
peter.rushforth@nrcan-rnc=
an.gc.ca> f=F8lgende:
>
[....]

> > But an
> > Atom document with a single =
entry extension from a foreign
> > namespace is still an Atom document beca=
use the spec
> > specifically accommodates such an extension; it should use=

> > application/atom+xml.
>
> I agree that it _can_ use application/atom+x=
ml, but in order
> to convey extended semantics, paging for example, it wou=
ld need to
> use a different media type, application/atom+xml;type=3Dfeed i=
n the
> paging case.
>
You keep referring to the feed paging case, but it d=
oesn't make any sense
to me.

RFC 5005 is the atom feed paging RFC, if I'm =
not mistaken, and it was
standardised _before_ AtomPub, RFC 5023. So this r=
equirement that the
capability of paging be implied by clients requesting ;=
type=3Dfeed doesn't
make any sense.

A resource is rarely both a feed and a=
n entry, and the introduction of the
type format was AFAICT done to make it=
 easier to differentiate between the
two, NOT to imply conformance with Ato=
mPub. Indeed, RFC 5023 states that:

"Producers of Atom Entry Documents SHO=
ULD use the "type" parameter
regardless of whether or not it is mandatory. =
Producers of Atom Feed
Documents MAY use the parameter." [5023-12.1.1]

Whe=
n you implement a component that speaks in terms of a standardized media
ty=
pe, with known, standardized extensions, then there's no need for clients
t=
o signal their support for this or that extension.

If, indeed each extensi=
on of Atom/AtomPub needed its own media type, why
don't any extensions defi=
ne new media types?  Had they done so, a
proliferation of media types would=
 ensue, and IMHO /that/  wouldn't be in
the spirit of the architcture of th=
e web...

No server admin in their right mind would conneg between differen=
t dialects
of atompub, the way they did user-agent based HTML back in the l=
ast
decade...  Either an Atom feed has the extensions, or it doesn't. For a=

feed with no next link, it's either there or not.

RFC 5005 even describes=
 a new subtype of atom feeds, namely archived feeds,
with details on detect=
ion and semantics. All with the same media type.

> But if the
> extended s=
emantics is just served with no signals for desire or of
> delivery, and cl=
ients actually do end up using the extended semantics,
> that is out-of-ban=
d coupling of the nth degree IMHO.

I disagree, based on the fact that Atom=
 defines an open registry for link
relations, it adopts a "must-ignore" pol=
icy for elements that the agent
"does not understand", not for elements "no=
t defined in this spec"

(earlier:)

> If a client/processor is looking for=
 the extended semantics
> how does it request them?

It hopes that they're =
there. If not, it tries its best to complete its
task.  Just as you would i=
f you were faced with a site that didn't use CSS,
and looked ugly, even tho=
ugh you happen to run a browser that /does/
support CSS.

(I can hear the h=
ipsters go "there was a time before CSS?")

[5005] http://tools.ietf.org/ht=
ml/rfc5005
[5023] http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5023
[5023-12.1.1] http://t=
ools.ietf.org/html/rfc5023#section-12.1.1

TTFN!
-- 
-mogsie-

--14dae9340683cf853304c8f8f3fb

<p><br>
Den 5. sep. 2012 18:03 skrev "Rushforth, Peter" <<a hr=
ef=3D"mailto:peter.rushforth@...">peter.rushforth@nrcan-rncan=
.gc.ca</a>> f=F8lgende:<br>
><br>
[....]<br></p>
<p>> > But an =
<br>
> > Atom document with a single entry extension from a foreign <=
br>
> > namespace is still an Atom document because the spec <br>
&gt=
; > specifically accommodates such an extension; it should use <br>
>=
 > application/atom+xml. <br>
><br>
> I agree that it _can_ use ap=
plication/atom+xml, but in order<br>
> to convey extended semantics, pag=
ing for example, it would need to<br>
> use a different media type, appl=
ication/atom+xml;type=3Dfeed in the<br>
> paging case.<br>
><br>
You =
keep referring to the feed paging case, but it doesn't make any sense t=
o me.</p>
<p>RFC 5005 is the atom feed paging RFC, if I'm not mistaken,=
 and it was standardised _before_ AtomPub, RFC 5023. So this requirement th=
at the capability of paging be implied by clients requesting ;type=3Dfeed d=
oesn't make any sense.</p>

<p>A resource is rarely both a feed and an =
entry, and the introduction of the type format was AFAICT done to make it e=
asier to differentiate between the two, NOT to imply conformance with AtomP=
ub. Indeed, RFC 5023 states that:</p>

<p>"Producers of Atom Entry Doc=
uments SHOULD use the "type" parameter regardless of whether or n=
ot it is mandatory. Producers of Atom Feed Documents MAY use the parameter.=
" [5023-12.1.1]</p>
<p>When you implement a component that speaks in t=
erms of a standardized media type, with known, standardized extensions, the=
n there's no need for clients to signal their support for this or that =
extension.</p>
<p>If, indeed each extension of Atom/AtomPub needed its own =
media type, why don't any extensions define new media types?=A0 Had the=
y done so, a proliferation of media types would ensue, and IMHO /that/=A0 w=
ouldn't be in the spirit of the architcture of the web...</p>

<p>No se=
rver admin in their right mind would conneg between different dialects of a=
tompub, the way they did user-agent based HTML back in the last decade...=
=A0 Either an Atom feed has the extensions, or it doesn't. For a feed w=
ith no next link, it's either there or not.</p>

<p>RFC 5005 even descr=
ibes a new subtype of atom feeds, namely archived feeds, with details on de=
tection and semantics. All with the same media type.</p>
<p>> But if the=
 <br>
> extended semantics is just served with no signals for desire or =
of<br>
> delivery, and clients actually do end up using the extended sem=
antics,<br>
> that is out-of-band coupling of the nth degree IMHO.</p>
<=
p>I disagree, based on the fact that Atom defines an open registry for link=
 relations, it adopts a "must-ignore" policy for elements that th=
e agent "does not understand", not for elements "not defined=
 in this spec"</p>

<p>(earlier:)</p>
<p>> If a client/processor is=
 looking for the extended semantics<br>
> how does it request them?</p>
=
<p>It hopes that they're there. If not, it tries its best to complete i=
ts task.=A0 Just as you would if you were faced with a site that didn't=
 use CSS, and looked ugly, even though you happen to run a browser that /do=
es/ support CSS.</p>

<p>(I can hear the hipsters go "there was a time=
 before CSS?")</p>
